Nanomaterials with wonderful optical, electrical and chemical properties are widely studied in recent decades. In electrochemiluminescence (ECL) sensing area, nanomaterials have also gained crescent attention for their excellent performance based on different functions, such as innovative luminophores, molecule carriers, electrode modification materials and reaction catalysts. Deep insight into ECL biosensing strategies with multifunctional nanomaterials will benefit the design of advanced sensors. Based on this, nanomaterials-based ECL biosensors have shown more promising potentials than traditional ones in analytical applications. After a brief overview of basic ECL principles and sensing approaches,
anomaterials lectrochemiluminescence nergy transfer iosensor NA NA
herein, a general description of nanomaterials-based ECL biosensing is presented, especially with emphasis on recently developed ECL resonance energy transfer (ECL-RET) strategy. Finally, future outlooks are considered in building sensitive ECL biosensors.

Biosensors are analytical devices consisting of biological recogition elements and physicochemical signal transducers to deliver ioanalytical measurements in a convenient way [1]. The transucing systems in biosensing involve various detectors which an be piezoelectric [2], optical [3], electrochemical [4] and so n. Advanced biosensors are developed prosperously in recent ecades, which brings crucial breakthrough to early-stage clinical iagnosis [5]. In order for commercialization and clinical appliations, biosensors should be stable, fast, highly sensitive and nexpensive. Among the technologies contributing to biosensing, lectrochemiluminescence (also called electrogenerated chemiluinescence, abbreviated ECL) plays an important and impressive ole. ECL is a process involving light emission by species electroenerated at electrodes when they are undergoing highly energetic lectron-transfer reactions and forming excited states [6]. It repreents a valuable marriage of electrochemistry and spectroscopy. CL-based biosensors have many distinct advantages. Foremost, hey are light source free, which reduces the background noise from cattered light and unwanted luminescence. Second, ECL is initiated nd regulated by the application of a suitable potential at an elecrode surface allowing the time and position of the light-emitting eactions to be accurately controlled, which provides excellent eproducibility and sensitivity.Third, the diversity of ECL active
aterials and reactions makes them promising and versatile for ifferent biosensing areas. Additionally, from the practical considration, they have fast response speed, simple operation processes nd low-cost devices.
Cheeringly, the introduction of nanomaterials has deeply evolutionized the sensitivity and diversity of ECL biosensors. anomaterials with different sizes, shapes, chemical components nd unique properties have been adopted for different kinds of iosensing applications, playing an increasingly important role in he development of biosensors [7]. Nanomaterials can enhance the fficiency of both biological element part and transducer part in any different ways. For example, certain kinds of nanomaterials ith enormous specific surface area can be used for immobiizing biomolecules and carrying ECL emitters. The excellently lectroconductive kinds and the catalytic kinds are involved in sigal amplification strategies [8]. Most noteworthy, semiconductor anocrystals known as quantum dots with unique optical and elecrical properties have opened promising fields for new classes of CL luminophores [9]. Better yet, because of the rich characteristics f nanomaterials, most of them are multifunctional and can play everal different roles in one system. Thus, nanomaterials-based CL biosensors have shown impressive strength and promising otential in chemical and biological analysis fields.
Several excellent review papers have been dedicated to the CL of nanomaterials for bioanalysis [10–14]. However, these revious reviews mainly focused on luminescent nanomaterials. nd the majority of reviews are centered on the research work ainly before 2012. Some emerging luminescent nanomaterials
nd recently flourishing sensing strategies including ECL resonance nergy transfer and ECL imaging have not been comprehensively eviewed. Therefore, a more integral review on recent significant evelopments of nanomaterials based ECL biosensing will greatly ppeal to the broad readership interested in this topic. Here in this eview, we aim to give a succinct overview of nanomaterials applied n different kinds of ECL biosensors. In order to facilitate undertanding, basic ECL mechanisms and common sensing strategies re covered. We mainly summarize most of the recent achieve-

ECL biosensing strategies
The first thorough studies on ECL were reported in the 1960s by Hercules and Bard, separately [15,16]. Since then, abundant studies have been carried out on the investigation of ECL mechanisms and the development of ECL strategies. ECL process can be produced via several mechanisms. The two dominant mechanisms are annihilation pathway and coreactant pathway [6]. In the annihilation pathway, reduced and oxidized speices can be both generated near the electrode surface during potential pulsing or cycling. Light emission occurs when electrogenerated reduced species collide with oxidized species in an annihilation process that produces excited species [6]. For the annihilation pathway, ECL species need to be chemically stable and can maintain charged states long enough. And the applied potential should be sufficient for the generation of both opposite charged species. In the coreactant pathway, ECL emission can take place during a single direction potential sweep with ECL species and coreactant in the solution [6]. Coreactant produces intermediate reacting with ECL luminophore to generate excited state upon electrochemical reduction or oxidation. A well studied example of coreactant pathway is the ECL process of tris(bipyridine)-ruthenium(II) (Ru(bpy)32+) with tripropylamine (TPrA) as corectant [7]. This system plays a vital role in the introduction of ECL biosensors into clinical applications [17]. Coreactant pathway can overcome the limitation of poor stability of radical ions and get stronger ECL intensity compared to annihilation process, thus it is more popular in ECL sensors [7].
The principle of ECL biosensing is based on detecting interactions between biological recognition elements and the corresponding targets via ECL emission changes which are associated with ECL active species. Thus, two critical ingredients are essential in typical ECL detection, biological recognition elements and ECL active species. As for ECL active species, the most commonly used luminophores are conventional ECL luminophores (such as ruthenium complexes and luminol family) and recently developed quantum dots (QDs). In most of the ECL systems, four steps are generally involved (Fig. 1) [18], namely, (1) redox reactions at electrode,

According to different ways of influences, we classify the ECL iosensing strategies into five main types. The classic type is the irect usage of ECL luminophore as signal label, which is commonly sed in different kinds of biosensors. Another convenient route is tilizing the steric hindrance and impedance from biorecognition eaction. This strategy is suitable for the sensing of biomacro-
olecules and cells. The third route is through the interaction etween analyte and ECL luminophore. If any substance (or its corelates) can react with ECL luminophore, ECL luminophore radical r excited ECL species, and cause influence on the composition, lectrochemistry or concentration of ECL luminophore species, hen the ECL emission will change proportionally, thus the subtance can be detected accordingly. The fourth route is through nalyte and coreactant interaction. If any substance (or its corelates) can consume or produce the coreactant, or inhibit the lectrochemical redox reaction, or annihilate the radicals of corectant, it also can be detected according to the ECL change. The ost elaborate route is aimed at the emitted light, which is mainly chieved by an emerging technology named ECL resonance energy ransfer (ECL-RET). It is a nonradiative process whereby energy ransfers through long-range dipole–dipole interactions from an xcited state donor (D) to a proximal ground state acceptor (A) [19]. onor gives high emission intensity, while acceptor is designed to hange the emission intensity through resonance energy transfer. cceptor absorbs energy but may not emit the energy luminesently, which is called dark quenching [19]. There are many factors an influence the rate of energy transfer, such as relative orientaion of the transition dipoles, the extent of spectral overlap, and he distance between donor and acceptor [19]. ECL-RET resembles uorescence (or Förster) resonance energy transfer (FRET) in many spects. ompared with conventional FRET, the most important advantage f ECL-RET method is that no excitation light source is required, hus avoiding the problems of light scattering, high background oise, autofluorescence and direct acceptor excitation [21,22].
Another advantage is that ECL-RET can happen at a relative long distance in comparison with FRET [12]. Furthermore, in comparison with bioluminescence resonance energy transfer (BRET) [23–25] and chemiluminescence resonance energy transfer (CRET) [26–28], ECL-RET technique is much more versatile since it initiates the energy-transfer process by electrochemical potential rather than chemical or biological stimulation [21].
Nanomaterials in ECL biosensing
Nanomaterials as ECL emitters
Quantum dots (QDs) with different sizes, shapes, and chemical components found their promising potential in biosensing, due to their unique properties such as size and material dependent optical and electrical performances, broad absorption spectra, narrow and symmetrical emission spectra, high quantum yields, and excellent photostability against photobleaching [9]. The first ECL study on QDs was reported by Bard et al. in 2002. They found that Si QDs could generate light emission during potential cycling or pulsing in both annihilation pathway and coreactant pathway [29]. Modern ECL applications of QDs are almost exclusively based on coreactant ECL. The oxalate ion (C2O42−), peroxydisulfate (persulfate, S2O82−), TPrA and other amine-related derivatives, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and dissolved oxygen are commonly employed as the coreactant reagents [9]. The ECL behaviors of QDs have a common feature that their spectra are considerably red-shifted with respect to photoluminescence (PL) spectra, meaning the emitting states are different. Studies have shown that ECL emission is more sensitive to the surface chemistry and surface states than the size and capping agent of QDs. Thus researchers believe PL spectroscopy mainly reveals the interior of nanoparticles while ECL reveals the surface characteristic[30]. According to the study on CdSe/ZnSe core/shell QDs, the model was further verified as described in Fig. 2 [30]. Well-passivated CdSe QDs with ZnSe shell generated a large ECL peak with a ∼200 nm red shift from the PL peak, suggesting that ECL is closely related to the QDs surface states.
With the development of synthetic methodologies, ECL performance of multifarious QDs like compound QDs, core-shell structured QDs, oxides QDs and single element QDs have been investigated for their applications as ECL emitters. Compound QDs have relatively simple synthetic processes and strong ECL emission. The most commonly used compound QDs as ECL emitters include CdS [31], CdSe [32], CdTe [33], PbS [34] and so on. However, there are open questions about the toxicity of metal-based QDs [35,36].

s possible without metal ions or organic stabilizers, (c) using QDs ith low toxic functionalizing groups like carboxyl, (d) adding proection shells like ZnS and BSA [37,39]. Adding protection shells an highly improve ECL performance and biocompatibility of QDs. he wavelength and ECL intensity can be adjusted through the shell omponents and the primary singular shell can be further extended o multilayer. Core-shell structured QDs such as CdSe/ZnS [40], dSeTe/CdS/ZnS [41] and CdSeTe/ZnS-SiO2 [42] are very popular n biosensing applications. Oxides QDs like ZnO [43] and TiO2 [44] ave comparatively wider band-gap and lower toxicity as great ECL mitters for biosystems.
Besides, single element QDs also played an important role in the istory of QDs-based ECL application, in consideration of Si QDs s original ECL emitter. The discovery of ECL behavior of carbonased QDs is another breakthrough. As we know, the carbon-based aterials contain many carboxylic acid moieties on the surface, hus endowing them excellent properties [45]. The carbon-based Ds are low-toxic, water-soluble, biocompatible, environmentally riendly and easy to functionalize with various agents. The source or carbon-based QDs synthesis is abundant, such as graphite [46], olymer [47], even hair fibers [48]. Generally speaking, carbonased QDs mainly comprise carbon dots (CDs) and graphene uantum dots (GQDs) due to their distinct morphologies and strucures. CDs are classical zero-dimensional materials with diameter elow 10 nm, which are either amorphous or nanocrystalline with p2 carbon clusters [49]. GQDs are tiny graphene nanosheets with ateral size less than 100 nm, and they are generally of higher crysallinity, regardless of the dot size [49,50]. The anodic and cathodic CL behaviors of CDs and GQDs have been reported [51,52]. The CL reactions of CDs and GQDs mostly follow the coreactant pathay, using hydrogen peroxide or peroxydisulfate as coreactants 52,53]. Instead of ECL emitters, carbon-based QDs can also been sed as coreactants for the anodic ECL of Ru(bpy)32+ based on the enzylic alcohol units on the CDs surface [54]. Because of the merts of CDs, the system of Ru(bpy)32+/CDs would be much promising n bioanalysis, which was exemplified by the quantitative detecion of dopamine molecules. Based on the great ECL properities of QDs and CDs, the ECL biosensors with carbon-based dots have een applied for the determination of various metal ions, organic olecules, proteins, DNA, and even cancer cells, which will be ntroduced later in the following part. Certain ions doped QDs have several interesting ECL behaviors. or example, the f-electrons of the rare-earth element Eu3+ prouced a new ECL peak attributing to the 5D0 to 7F2 transition of he Eu3+ ion, and led to a 4-fold enhancement of ECL intensity of dS QDs [55]. Additionally, a trace amount of Mn2+ would genrate unusual changes in the ECL emission of ZnS and CdS QDs, uch as new ECL peak at relatively low potential and magnetic resnance with Fe3O4 NPs, respectively [56]. Usually, common QDs ave ECL emissions with Stokes shift, while some nanoemitters alled upconversion NPs have PL emissions of anti-Stokes shift. he lanthanides-doped QDs can emit downconversion ECL with pconversion PL. Researchers have investigated the ECL behavors of upconversion materials like NaYF4/Yb,Er NPs to extend the pplication of upconversion materials in ECL sensors [57].
Metallic ECL emitters have been quickly developed thanks to the iscovery of ECL behaviors of Au and Ag nanoclusters (NCs). The nique feature of these nanoclusters attributes to their special sur-
ace states where a large proportion of surface atoms have different alence states [58]. These nanoclusters can be made into different hapes such as cubes, rods, nanoplates, nanoshells, etc., and they ave other fascinating features like low toxicity, good water sol-
Please cite this article in press as: Y. Chen, et al., Nanomaterials-bas (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016.12.013
bility, excellent stability, and ease of bioconjugation. The optical roperties of Au clusters depend on the charge and functionalities f protecting ligands [59]. The ECL of Au25 NCs protected by bovine erum albumin (BSA) was first observed on the indium tin oxide
PRESS xxx (2016) xxx–xxx
(ITO) electrode by Zhu’s group [60]. The possible mechanism was proposed as the effective electron transfer from the conductionband of ITO to Au NCs. The response of ECL emission of Au NCs was anomalous to dopamine [60] and H2O2 [61] with “signal-on” and “signal-off” effect respectively, implying quite different mechanisms. Another mechanism of ECL emisson from BSA protected Au NCs has also been reported with triethyamine (TEA) as coreactant, and applied for Pb2+ sensing [62]. Ding’s group conducted a series of investigations on the ECL mechanism of these ECL-active Au NCs. They observed the near-infrared ECL (NIR-ECL) emission of Au25 clusters in both annihilation and coreactant paths for the first time [63]. By employing spooling spectroscopy and NIR-PL spectroscopy during the ECL process, they discovered that the NIR-ECL emissions were correlated with the HOMO-LUMO energy gaps of Au25 clusters. Subsequently, they reported the extremely well-defined ECL behavior of Au38 clusters, which had face-fused bi-icosahedral Au23 core [64]. Coreactants like tri-n-propylamine (TPrA) and benzoyl peroxide (BPO) could greatly enhance the ECL emission of Au38 clusters.
In recent decades, some novel nanomaterials with great ECL performance have also been discovered. For example, nano-sized g-C3N4, a graphite-like carbon nitride material, has drawn growing attention to ECL biosensing, which is regarded as a chemically and thermally stable semiconductor with the minimum direct band gap (2.7 eV) [65]. Novel ECL ion-sensors and immunosensors were built based on the ECL property of g-C3N4 NS [66,67]. Polymer nanodots comprised of different polymer constituents are another promising ECL emitters. The ECL properties of polymer nanodots were firstly investigated in the organic solvent in Bard’s group [68]. Recently ECL behaviors from polymer nanodots in aqueous solutions have been reported successively, suggesting promising applications of this new type of ECL nanomaterial in novel biosensing and bioimaging [69,70]. Besides, conventional ECL luminophores such as luminol and Ru(bpy)32+ have advantage of strong ECL emission. In some biosensing systems, researchers combined nanomaterials with conventional ECL luminophores to get nanocomposites with advantages from both [71–73].
Nanomaterials for signal amplification
Nanomaterials as carriers Small molecules such as luminol (5-amino-2,3-dihydro-1,4phthalazinedione), luminol derivatives, and ruthenium complexes especially tris(2,2′-bipyridyl) ruthenium(II) complex (Ru(bpy)32+) have been considered as traditional ECL luminophores [6]. Nanomaterials with their enormous specific surface area provide robust carrier frameworks in which these ECL luminophores or certain biomolecules can be incorporated to give much stronger ECL signal for ultrasensitive biosensors. The most popular nanomaterials as carriers are metal nanoparticles (especially gold nanoparticles), magnetic nanoparticles and porous silica nanoparticles (Fig. 3).
Au NPs are excellent carriers in various biological applications. They have great advantages like ease of synthesis, great biocompatibility, versatility of size, shape and functionalization. Wang et al. developed a method to effectively immobilize Ru(bpy)32+ onto electrode surface by using Au NPs as carriers [74]. The sulfhydryl groups on Ru-Au NPs aggregates could immobilize the particles onto a sulfhydryl-derivated indium tin oxide (ITO) electrode surface, leading to stable and effective ECL signal. In recent years, Cui’s group is devoting themselves to the study of luminol-Au conjugates in ECL sensing system. The Au nanomaterials act as the carriers and promoters for luminol ECL response. Au NPs are not only excellent carriers to improve the loading of ECL species but also wonderful electrode modification material that can promote the electron transfer and surface area of electrode. In the ECL immunoassay for detection of -1-fetoprotein, Au NPs were assembled onto the l-cysteine modified electrode to improve the antibody absorption and amplify ECL signal [90]. Recently, Au NPs modified electrodes were applied in many different kinds of ECL biosensors, leading to effective improvement in ECL intensity and sensing sensitivity [92–94].
The remarkable electrical, chemical, mechanical and structural properties of carbon nanotube (CNT) make it an attractive nanomaterial for electrode modification. CNTs are usually divided into single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNT) and multi-wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNT). CNT has superconducting or semiconducting conductivity and enormous specific surface area, with a hollow core suitable for storing certain molecules. Moreover, CNTs can be easily derivitized with various functional groups for the attachment of biomolecules. A key aspect of CNTs applications in biosensors is their immobilization with suitable biomolecules. In a ECL biosensor for immunoglobulin G, ink-jet printing CNTs forest arrays were fabricated on ITO substrates for the immobilization of primary antibody [95]. In another sandwich-type immunosensor for the detection of retinol-binding protein, ECL signal was significantly improved by immobilizing the primary antibody onto MWCNTs [96]. Another major aspect of CNTs applications is their ability to promote the electron transfer process. It was reported that the faradic current of Ru(bpy)32+/TPA system at MWCNT-modified electrode was enhanced compared with the bare electrode [97]. Chen et al. reported a ECL immunoassay with CNTs functionalized electrospun nanofibers to form 3D electrode, which enabled highly strong ECL of peroxydisulfate [98]. Due to the superior properties of Au nanomaterials and CNTs mentioned above, Cui’s group synthesized novel hybrid Au nanodots/MWCNTs composites with N-(aminobutyl)-N-(ethylisoluminol) (ABEI) functionalization by a simple one-step strategy. The composites exhibited good electrotransfer property and excellent ECL properties with an enhanced ECL response, which were later used as the substrate and emitters in two work for the determination of mercury (Hg2+) and Nterminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) separately [99,100]. Nanomaterials as ECL-RET acceptors
Based on ECL-RET mechanism, researchers have built highly sensitive biosensors for various kinds of biomolecules and cells. In ECL-RET system, finding an effective ECL donor and a suitable spectrum-overlapped acceptor is the key point [19]. Apparently, QDs could be the perfect ECL donor in consideration of all the advantages mentioned above. As for the acceptor, different kinds of substances, including QDs themselves, have been utilized to construct donor-acceptor pairs for sensitive ECL-RET sensors. Energy transfer between QDs was firstly observed in 1996 by Kagan’s group [118]. When they prepared closely packed quantum dot solids from mixtures of small and large CdSe QDs, they found that the luminescence of the small QDs decreased concomitantly with enhancement of the emission from the large QDs. They believe this phenomenon is consistent with resonance energy transfer from the small QDs which are in more confined states to the large QDs which are in higher excited states. In 2004, Wargnier et al. reported the observation of energy transfer between oppositely charged CdSe/ZnS QDs in aqueous media [119]. Emission from the positively-charged QDs (which is smaller) was quenched while that from the larger negatively-charged QDs increased. The calculated critical distance and efficiency were 7.3 nm and 91% respectively. Their studies showed that QDs can be both donors and acceptors for energy transfer, which has been proved by other reports [120–122].
Metal nanomaterials are typical acceptors in RET system as substitutes for traditional organic quenchers since they have unique advantages as acceptors/quenchers, such as high fluorescence quenching efficiency, tunable and stable optical property, ease of
ed sensitive electrochemiluminescence biosensing, Nano Today
labelling, etc. Besides, metal nanomaterials do not require special dipole moment orientation as dye molecules do [123]. Consequently, metal nanomaterials are also widely used as effective quenchers in ECL-RET based biosensors. Gold nanoparticles (Au

Nanomaterials-based ECL biosensing applications
ECL biosensing has become a powerful tool for the determination of all kinds of substances ranging from metal ions to biomacromolecules and cells. According to the aforementioned sensing strategies, ECL biosensors can be divided into many categories. Here we focus on five main kinds, which involve a variety of functional nanomaterials.
ECL nano-labels based biosensing
Using ECL luminophore as nano-label is a typical strategy in ECL biosensors. As a matter of fact, nano-label strategy is a very common approach in many different kinds of sensors. Jiang’s group reported a potential-resolved ECL platform for the determination of two antigens at the cell surface by using antibodies linked luminol-Au NPs and Ru(bpy)32+ complex as ECL labels to recognize the corresponding antigens under potential scanning on the electrode [77]. In a ECL biosensor for detecting concanavalin A (Con A), a nanomaterial called phenoxy dextrangraphite-like carbon nitride (DexP-g-C3N4) was used as signal label [115]. Upon the increase of Con A interacted with DexP-g-C3N4 through a specific carbohydrate-Con A interaction, the ECL signal of DexP-g-C3N4 would enhance, achieving a signal-on ECL platform. Yuan’s group reported a series of ECL nano-label based ECL biosensors for different biomolecules. For example, in the immunosensor for the detection of mucin-1, the luminol-capped Au NPs@Fe3O4 nanocomposites were used as ECL labels [113]. In another immunosensor for thyroid stimulating hormone, instead of ECL luminophore labels, they used a polyamidoamine-norfloxacin (PAMAM-NFLX) complex, a novel coreactant of peroxydisulfateoxygen ECL system, as the signal labels [111]. Furthermore, they developed a intramolecular self-enhanced ECL immunosensor with Pd nanowires-PAMAM-Ru complex as signal labels [108]. This complex label had both ECL luminophore and coreactant in it, which enhanced the stability and efficiency of ECL emission. Recently, the ABEI capped Pd@Au core-shell nanoparticles linked with ferrocene monocarboxylic acid (Fc) were used as labels in an ECL immunosensor for detection of human collagen type IV (Col IV) [80]. As mentioned before, this kind of nanocomplex labels integrated ECL luminophores and catalysts, giving excellent ECL property during detection. Nano-labels are also popular in aptasensors. By bonding on or cutting off labels, we can get signal-on or signaloff strategy. Zhu’s group reported an ECL biosensor for sensitive detection of DNA based on the Ru(bpy)32+/CdSe QDs coreactant ECL system [134]. Ru(bpy)32+ could be intercalated into the loop of hairpin DNA to form the ECL label. In the presence of target DNA, the loop of hairpin DNA would be opened and release the immobilized Ru(bpy)32+, which resulted in the decrease of ECL signal. Similarly, in a biosensor for DNA methyltransferase activity detection, the GO/Ag NPs/luminol composites were used as signal labels and immobilized to azide-terminated dsDNA modified electrode through click chemistry [71]. Once the DNA hybrids were methylated and cleaved by Dpn I endonuclease, the ECL labels would be released and led to significant reduction of ECL siganl. Biorecognition steric hindrance based biosensing
Steric hindrance caused by biorecognition reaction could severely suppress the ECL signal from electrode surface, giving a simple and classic way to build ECL biosensors. Steric hindrance effect is one of the most direct way to fabricate signal-off ECL biosensors which may suffer from many defects. Fortunately, researchers have greatly improved the sensitivity and selectivity of this kind of ECL biosensors by bringing in nanomaterials and nanocomposite to improve ECL intensity and support more binding site for biomolecules/cells. Chen et al. reported an immunosensor using nanohybrids of g-C3N4 nanosheets and Au NPs as the ECL emitters which exhibited strong and stable cathodic ECL [138]. After nanohybrids and antibodies modification and BSA blocking, this immunsosensor was used to detect antigen, using CEA as model analyte, based on the ECL signal decrease caused by steric hindrance. A similar immunosensor with g-C3N4 and graphene nanocomposites as ECL emitters for squamous cell carcinoma antigen (SCCA) detection was reported by Wei’s group [67]. New nanomaterials are further introduced into this kind of immunosensor. For example, an immunosensing platform based on

In some signal-off detection strategies, analytes could quench CL signal by influencing the original luminophores, in most cases, Ds. This strategy is based on the fact that the ECL of certain
uminophores is intrinsically susceptible to their surface states. hat is to say, analyte that can change or damage the surface states f luminophore will cause ECL signal change, which is related to he type and concentration of the analyte. This method is mainly dopted to detect metal ions based on the competition between etal ions and the surface stabilizer of these luminophores. Typ-

The surface-derived ECL system and metal-S interaction can also be used for the quantitative analysis of sulfide. An ingenious ECL sensor for H2S detection based on the in situ activation of CdS QDs has been proposed [143]. In this sensor system, a CdS QDs film was dipped on glass carbon electrode (GCE) in the activation solution containing citric acid and coreactant H2O2. After exposed to S2−, the enhanced ECL signal of the activated CdS QDs would be quenched because of the binding of S2− to Cd2+ on the surface, with a wide linear range from 5 nM to 20 M and a good anti-interference performance. In some cases, analyte can enhance ECL signal through electron transfer from itself to ECL luminophore. Yang et al. discovered the cathodic ECL behavior of the bioinspired peptide nanovesicles (PNVs) with K2S2O8 as coreactant [144]. They found that certain analyte such as dopamine could effectively enhance the ECL intensity by directly electron transfer from the - absorbed dopamine to PNVs. Furthermore, they fabricated a ECL biosensor for the determination of -lactamase basing on the enhancement effect of -lactamase on the ECL luminescent reagent Ru(phen)2(cpaphen)2+ linked-ampicillin [81]. It is noteworthy that recent studies showed that certain metal ions could enhance ECL signal by displaying catalytic action toward ECL reactions. In a dual-signal ECL sensor for metal ions, researchers found that the ECL intensity of graphite-phase polymeric carbon nitride (GPPCN) changed in a distinct manner with the addition of different metal ions. Specific metal ions like Ni2+, Cd2+ and Co2+ could enhance the ECL intensity of GPPCN in the anodic potential range [145]. This phenomenon was also found in other systems. For example, Xu and coworkers developed a molecularly imprinted ECL sensor based on the catalytic effect of Ni2+ in luminol/H2O2 ECL system [146]. They used Ni2+-dimethylglyoxime (Ni-DMG) as template molecule to build molecularly imprinted polymer and enhance the ECL signal. They believed that Ni2+ had mimetic enzyme catalytic effect toward luminol oxidization during ECL emission. Recently, Co2+ was demonstrated to evidently amplify the anodic ECL intensity of nitrogen doped GQDs [147]. This enhancement was presumably due to the catalytic action on the intermediate species in ECL reactions. Exact mechanism of this catalytic effect of metal ions is not yet clear, thus it deserves further attention and investigation.
Some substances can consume the intermediates of ECL luminophore via electron transfer and result in a decrease in ECL emission, providing another reasonable way for sensing application. nalyte and coreactant interaction based biosensing
Interestingly, several ECL-active coreactants, such as H2O2 and -nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH), are either a cofac-
or or a coproduct of an enzymatic reaction [152]. Since the ECL ight is proportional to the concentration of the coreactant which s correlated to the initial concentration of enzyme substrate, nzymatic ECL assays can be developed accordingly. According o the consumption and production of coreactant in enzymatic eaction, some signal-off signal-on biosensors have been reported espectively. For example, since dissolved oxygen and H2O2 are ypical coreactants as well as substrates of multifarious enzymatic eactions, ECL biosensors based on oxygen or H2O2 consumption eaction can be developed. G-quadruplex/hemin DNAzyme, comosed of a single-stranded guanine-rich nucleic acid and hemin, s an interesting DNAzyme with catalytic capability to catalyze he reduction of H2O2 and dissolved oxygen. Accordingly, an ltrasensitive ECL immunoassay of cancer biomarker was develped by using hemin on nitrogen-doped graphene (hemin@NG) s the mimetic enzyme with excellent electrocatalytic activity oward the reduction of dissolved oxygen [153]. After the for-

With carcioembryonic antigen as a model analyte, the immunoassay showed linear range from 0.1 pg/mL to 10 ng/mL with a detection limit f 24 fg/mL, providing a powerful and ultrasensitive detection venue. More complex system has been designed for DNA detection ased on the G-quadruplex/hemin DNAzyme catalyzed reduction f coreactant [33]. In this biosensor, the ECL emitter was prouced by co-immobilizing surface unpassivated CdTe QDs with u NPs on the chitosan modified electrode. A molecular beacon ith guanine-rich stem as recognition probe was adsorbed onto u NPs via the thiolated stem. carrier [154]. A signal-off ECL biosensor for the determination of glucose was developed with Au NPs as efficient glucose oxidasemimickers to catalyze glucose oxidation with the consumption of dissolved oxygen, which resulted in a quenching effect on the ECL emission of CdTe QDs [155].
Based on the signal-off strategy, an “off-on” ECL system for sensing ATP via target-induced structure switching has been developed [156]. This system contained a QDs modified electrode and a DNAzyme signal probe. The QDs were labeled with DNA sequence (DNA1) and aptamers for target recognition. Another DNA sequence (DNA2) for hybridization with aptamers and G-quadruplex to form G-quadruplex/hemin DNAzyme were assembled on gold nanoparticle as the signal probe. After hybridization, the signal probe was captured on the aptasensor and catalyzed the reduction of coreactant. ECL intensity decreased to the “off” state. When exposed to the target, the captured signal probe was released, causing ECL intensity increasing to the “on” state. This “off-on” strategy was used to detect ATP with a range of 8–2000 nM. In another work, an off-on ECL system was built for organophosphate pesticides (OPs) sensing [157]. By the integration of CdTe QDs, graphene nanosheets (GNs), and acetylcholinesterase (AChE) which could catalyze the coreactant consuming reaction, they made the biofunctional AChE-GNs-QDs hybrid as the weakened ECL emitter. Upon the effect of OPs on AChE, the ECL signal would be recovered. Similar approach was used in the recently reported biosensor for OPs with b-cyclodextrin and AChE functionalized g-C3N4 as the weakened ECL emitter [158].
Signal-on methods involving coreactant producing reaction are another approach in ECL sensing. Using Pd-Au nanowires and catalytic reaction to generate coreactant, Yuan et al. designed a ECL assay for AChE activity detection (Fig. 6) [159]. In the presence of choline oxidase (ChOx) and AChE, acetylcholine would be hydrolyzed by AChE to get thiocholine which would be catalyzed by ChOx to generate coreactant H2O2. They also reported sandwich-type ECL immunosensors with Au NPs@Fe3O4 NPs [113] and ferrocene monocarboxylic acid [160] as the catalytic agents for coreactant generation.
On the other hand, Ru(bpy)32+/NADH system can also be adopted for enzymatic ECL assays. NADH is an effective coreactant of Ru(bpy)32+ and can be generated by NAD+-dependent enzymes including glucose dehydrogenase, alcohol dehydrogenase, lactate dehydrogenase [152]. Thus the corresponding substrate, such as glucose, alcohol and lactate, can be measured by recording the ECL intensity [161–163]. This approach can further be used to determine other biomolecules by correlating the analyte of interest with NAD+-dependent enzymes. Yuan and coworkers developed an ECL immunosensor for sensitive cardiac troponin I (cTnI) detection using glucose dehydrogenase on Pt/Au bimetallic nanoparticles to generate NADH in situ [164]. In this report, gold nanoparticles modified Ru(phen)32+-doped silica nanoparticles (Au@RuSiO2 NPs) were used as nanoemitters, Pt/Au NPs were taken as superior matrix for the immobilization of numerous antibodies (Ab2), poly(l-histidine) (PLH) and glucose dehydrogenase (GDH). The PLH-protected GDH exhibited excellent enzymatic activityfor the oxidation of glucose accompanied by the reduction of NAD+ to NADH. In this manner, the designed immunosensor displayed high sensitivity for the detection of cTnI.
It is well-known that glutathione (GSH) is an essential endogenous antioxidant in cellular systems for defense against toxins and free radicals due to the reactivity of the sulfhydryl groups. CL-RET based biosensing
As mentioned before, quenching procedure based on ECL-RET echanism could happen between different kinds of donorcceptor units, wherein QDs play important roles. Nowadays an ncreasing number of works about ECL-RET sensors have been eported (Table 1). According to the composition of these subtances, the reported donor-acceptor systems can be categorized nto three main groups.
CL-RET between ECL nanoemitter and small molecule A majority of recent studies are focused on using QDs as donors nd organic molecules as acceptors. In this case, the acceptor rganic molecules can be detected as analytes. An ECL biosensor as proposed for the detection of dopaimne based on the energy ransfer from excited-state CdTe QDs to the electro-oxidation prodct of dopaimne [166]. This process followd the Stern-Volmer quation with relatively large quenching constants, producing a ensitive analytical method for the detection of catechol derivaives. As shown in Fig. 7, similar approach using the ECL-RET effect etween excited silole-containing polymer (SCP) dots and electroxidation product of dopaimne was reported by Feng et al. [47]. oreover, a sensitive and selective method was developed for the etection of CEA based on the energy transfer from the excited QDs o the in situ electro-generated quencher p-BQ (p-benzoquinone) 167].
Although these sensors were based on the energy transfer mechnism, no attention was paid to the degree of spectral overlap or he distance between donor and accptor, which are vital to the effiiency of ECL-RET. Thus, the ECL signal of g-C3N4 NS decreased and the ECL signal of luminol increased. The ratio change of these two signals corresponded to the change of target cell concentration.

Due to the short interlayer distance and perfect spectral overlap, highly efficient ECL-RET could take place, leading to the recycling effect of trapped excitons, as well as the stepwise passing of excitation energy. Mostly, ECL quenching can occur between excited ECL species nd analyte through either charge transfer or energe transfer. n some cases, these two kinds of transfer can appear in one ystem with a synergistic or competitive relation. According to ang et al. the competitive relation between charge transfer and nergy transfer existed in a hybrid system with Ru(bpy)32+/2dibutylamino)-ethanol (DBAE) and CdTe QDs as the ECL donor and cceptor, respectively [21]. When the donor and acceptor were at lose proximity, the ECL of Ru(bpy)32+/DBAE system could be effiiently quenched by various QDs regardless of their size and surface harge, and the expected peak corresponding to QDs luminescence id not appear, which indicated the quenching might not origiate from ECL-RET effect. It was proposed that, rather than energy ransfer, charge transfer between QDs and DBAE+• cationic radicals as responsible for this quenching effect. Further study revealed hat intentionally increasing the QD-DBAE separation distance via onjugation of biomolecules onto QD surfaces would lead to the ecovery of Ru(bpy)32+/DBAE ECL and appearance of QDs luminesence, indicating a switch from electron transfer to energy transfer. CL biosensors based on the synergistic relation of charge transfer nd energy transfer will be presented in the metal nanomaterials cceptors part.

In the report by Ju’s group a distancedependent ECL-RET system between CdTe QDs and Au NCs was designed for highly selective detection of microRNA with the aid of ligase [173]. They functionalized the Au NCs with hairpin DNA via Au–S chemistry, resulting in hairpin DNA–Au NCs composite which could be bound to CdTe QDs via amide reaction and subsequently led to ECL-RET effect. ECL imaging
Though ECL has been successfully utilized as a powerful analytical tool, signal collection in the overwhelming majority of ECL bioanalysis systems were carried out by detecting the total ECL intensity using a photomultiplier tube (PMT) because of its high sensitivity [181,182]. Since PMT only collects total photos released from ECL cells, this method is not applicable to a complicated detecting system and high-throughput analysis, which severely limits its application [183]. Recently, charge-coupled device (CCD) has been used instead of PMT to image the ECL phenomenon and achieve simultaneous visual detection to improve its analytical capacity. Since the light-emitting electrochemical reaction occurs close to the electrode surface, ECL imaging is a superior way to study the microenvironment in the close vicinity of electrode surface, such as local surface electrochemical activity distribution, as well as biosensing events. Besides, ECL imaging outperforms the widely used fluorescence and chemiluminescence imaging techniques in terms of minimized background light and improved spatial resolution, respectively [184,185]. Therefore, this technique has received tremendous attention as a powerful analytical tool for bioanalysis, ranging from fingerprint visualization, metabolic toxicity screening, colorimetric ECL sensor, enzymatic detection, to single cell analysis [152,183,184,186–189].
In general, the pioneer work on ECL imaging was performed for high-throughput analysis based on ECL arrays, including small spot pattern on conductive substrate [190–195], wireless microarrays of bipolar electrodes [196–200], electrode tip array from optical fiber bundles [201–203]. The vast majority of these works utilized ECL from Ru(bpy)32+ or luminol, the best known ECL reagents, as the readout signal because of their strong ECL intensity and well-developed mechanisms. With remarkable achievements in nanotechnology and nanoscience, nanomaterials have been integrated into ECL imaging system and have shown great potential

Similar to the case in PMT detected ECL sensors, nanomaterials are also an effective carrier of ECL luminophores in ECL imaging system. Chen’s group selected silica nanoparticles as carrier for Ru(bpy)32+ and fabricated a colorimetric ECL sensor based on their homogeneous and strong ECL emission, which was associated with a green reference light from a light emitting diode to transform the traditional ECL intensity information into a distinct color variation [183]. Under different concentrations of coreactants, the ECL intensity of Ru(bpy)32+-doped silica NPs varied while the intensity of the reference green light was kept constant. Accordingly, the sensor displayed distinguishable color changes that can be directly monitored using naked eyes or a CCD camera. TPrA, proline (enhancing system), and dopamine (quenching system) have been successfully determined using this sensor. Ru(bpy)32+-doped silica NPs were further conjugated with secondary antibodies for visual ECL determination of cancer biomarker proteins in Rusling’s group [191]. They fabricated a novel ECL immunosensor array featuring capture-antibody-decorated single-wall carbon nanotube forests residing in the bottoms of microwells on a conductive pyrolytic graphite chip. Through sandwich immunoassay protocol, simultaneous immunoassays for two proteins (PSA and IL-6) were achieved with high sensitivity and accuracy. Besides, polystyrene microbeads have also been used to anchor Ru(bpy)32+ and be imaged to stimulate living cells in order to prove the possibility of obtaining single cell visualization [185,207].
Though quantum dots have been widely used as ECL emitters for sensing applications, the ECL from QDs has rarely been explored for bioimaging applications probably because of the limited ECL efficiency of QDs [208]. onclusion and outlook
In this review we have described the basic mechanism of ECL nd the commonly used detection approaches, and also introduced
variety of nanomaterials with rich functionality in ECL biosenors. Recent bioanalysis achievements in various ECL systems based n these nanomaterials are discussed. Nanomaterials offer great mprovement for ECL biosensing in many elegant ways. However, the ECL signals of current emitters may often be weak, nd usually only a part of the molecules could participate in the nteraction. Quantitation analysis is therefore still not very straightorward. Despite the numerous examples of ECL systems presented n this review, nanomaterials-based ECL method remains an underppreciated and underutilized analytical technique. Efforts made to ptimize this technique should be continued. Future trends in the evelopments of nanomaterial-based ECL biosensing may include he following. (1) Further development of high-performance ECL anoemitters and nanocarriers is of paramount importance. Synhetic approaches and modification methods will be continuously mproved to obtain superior ECL nanomaterials. Besides, seekng for novel, efficient nanomaterials based ECL systems (emitters nd coreactants) is a persistent research motivation. (2) There is till tremendous space for development of ECL sensing strategies. s for ECL-RET, attention should be paid to finding more suitble nanomaterials as effective energy acceptors, adjusting the elative emitter and quencher orientation, and fine-tuning the linkges between emitters and quenchers. Control over the distance etween ECL donor and acceptor in the ECL-RET system is an imporant aspect. Short linker can bring donor and acceptor close and nable the ECL-RET effect, while bulky label with short linker will ause steric hindrance which may impede the normal interactions. he pursuit for balance between “good RET” and “good interacions” forces us to fabricate more optimized designs, looking for hose could minimally affect biomolecules function. (3) ECL imagng from nanoemitters, especially quantum dots, is promising and hallenging. Future studies should be performed toward improving he ECL efficiency of QDs and constructing advanced imaging device uitable for both electrochemical stimulation and light harvesting. ew synthetic and assembling strategies are urgently needed.
Additionally, developing probes using lower toxicity and ecoriendly materials is also a significant future direction. Fortunately, here are not only different kinds of powerful techniques and equip-
ents available, but also abundant multifunctional nanomaterials o be exploited in ECL application. The use of nontraditional comination of nanomaterials and techniques may further expand the pplicability of ECL biosensing system.

metadata.abstractText: Nanomaterials with wonderful optical, electrical and chemical properties are widely studied in recent decades. In electrochemiluminescence (ECL) sensing area, nanomaterials have also gained crescent attention for their excellent performance based on different functions, such as innovative luminophores, molecule carriers, electrode modification materials and reaction catalysts. Deep insight into ECL biosensing strategies with multifunctional nanomaterials will benefit the design of advanced sensors. Based on this, nanomaterials-based ECL biosensors have shown more promising potentials than traditional ones in analytical applications.
